intro: Rosa canina var. rhynchocarpa, commonly known as the sea rose or dog rose, is a variant of the common dogwood rose. It is a shrub that typically grows in coastal areas and is characterized by its thorny stems and fragrant pink or white flowers. The plant produces small, red, berry-like fruits that are often used in traditional medicine and culinary applications. Its leaves are serrated and have a slightly hairy texture, while its flowers are usually borne in clusters at the ends of the branches. This variety is well adapted to saline environments and is often found in maritime climates.
